title: 112_s1445
content: The Act is titled the "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Raechel and Jacqueline Houck Safe Rental Car Act of 2011" defines a "covered vehicle" as a motor vehicle rated at 26,000 pounds gross vehicle weight or less, rented or leased without a driver, and part of a fleet of 5 or more vehicles used for rental or lease purposes. It also defines terms like "defect", "motor vehicle", "motor vehicle safety", and "motor vehicle safety standard". The term "person" is defined as given in section 1 of title 1, United States Code. A "rental company" is a person engaged in renting or leasing 5 or more covered vehicles for rental or lease purposes. PROHIBITION ON RENTAL, LEASE, AND SALE OF DEFECTIVE CARS AND TRUCKS. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of covered vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance. Prohibition on rental, lease, or sale of vehicles with safety defects or non-compliance, unless the issue has been resolved before the transaction. Exceptions apply if a notification ordered by the Secretary is challenged in a civil action. Rental companies must act upon receiving a notification of a safety defect in a covered vehicle during a rental or lease period. The notification is considered received 5 business days after being mailed. Rental companies must immediately inform renters and offer a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost if the covered vehicle has a safety defect or does not comply with safety standards. Rental companies must provide a comparable alternative vehicle at no extra cost until the defect is fixed. This section will be effective 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce the provisions of the Act, effective 60 days after enactment. Violation of section 3 of this Act will be treated as a violation of a rule under the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The Federal Trade Commission will enforce this Act with the same powers and duties as under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Penalties will apply to those who violate this Act or its regulations. The Act's provisions are subject to penalties and privileges under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Commission's authority is not limited by this section. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT BY STATES. The attorney general of a State can bring an action in a US district court for violations of the Act to obtain injunctive relief. The Federal Trade Commission must be notified in certain cases. The attorney general of a State can seek injunctive relief in a civil action under the Act. The Federal Trade Commission must be notified before initiating such action. The State must provide a copy of the complaint to the attorney general before initiating a civil action. If the attorney general cannot provide notice, the State must do so immediately upon filing the action. The Federal Trade Commission may intervene in the action upon receiving the required notice. Upon receiving notice required by paragraph (1) in a civil action, the Federal Trade Commission can intervene, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. This section does not prevent State attorney generals from exercising their powers. The section prohibits State attorney generals from interfering with the powers of the authorized State officer. No separate suit can be brought if the alleged violation is already being addressed by the Federal Trade Commission or the United States. SEC. 6 of the Act clarifies that individuals can seek remedies under Federal or State law. SEC. 7 requires a report from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on sales of vehicles to rental companies without standard safety features. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress within 180 days on the sales of motor vehicles to rental companies without standard safety features. The report will include a description of rental companies' buying practices for vehicles lacking these safety features. The Administrator must report to Congress on rental companies selling motor vehicles without standard safety features, including implications on consumer safety and recommendations for regulatory actions. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on rental companies selling vehicles with safety defects before recalls. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration must report to Congress on sales of rental vehicles that may have safety defects or not comply with safety standards within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. During the period when rental companies are aware of potential safety defects or non-compliance with standards, they must take action until they receive a notification from the Secretary of Transportation. The report required by the Secretary of Transportation under section 30118 of title 49, United States Code, must include elements specified in paragraph (2). The report required by the Secretary of Transportation under section 30118 of title 49, United States Code, must include a description and analysis of the frequency of sales of covered vehicles, a discussion of the effects of such sales on consumers, and recommendations on legislative and administrative actions to address or mitigate these effects. A follow-up report is required within 1 year. The Administrator must submit a follow-up report to Congress within 1 year after the initial report on the sales of covered vehicles, including a description of the sales frequency, effects on consumers, and recommendations for addressing or mitigating these effects. The follow-up report to Congress must include a description, analysis, discussion, and recommendations for the period specified, as well as an identification and analysis of differences in findings compared to the initial report. The follow-up report to Congress must include a discussion of the effects of the provisions of this Act on the sales of covered vehicles as described in subsection (a)(1).
